_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This facility started production operations in 1992 and expanded the refrigeration capacity in September 2010.

The Ajinomoto Frozen Foods refrigeration system uses pure anhydrous ammonia (a commonly used refrigerant for industrial systems) as the refrigerant in a closed-circuit system (not exposed to the atmosphere).   Anhydrous ammonia is listed as a regulated toxic substance in Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68.130) with a threshold quantity (TQ) of 10,000 lbs.  EPA requires facilities with threshold quantities or greater of a regulated substance to prepare and maintain a Risk Management Program (RMP).

The original system constructed in 1992, the Frick system, meets design specifications in ANSI/IIAR 2-1984, Equipment, Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigeration Systems and ANSI/ASHRAE-15, 1989, Safety Code for Mechanical Refrigeration.  All pressure vessels are built according to American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), Section VIII, Division 1, 1989 Edition (with 1990b Addendum), Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Pressure Vessels (or later editions).  Refrigeration piping design and construction was in accordance with ASME B31.5, 1987, Refrigeration Piping code.  Electrical design and construction was performed in accordance with NFPA-70, 1987, National Electrical Code.

The system constructed in 2010, the Mycom system, meets design specifications in ANSI/IIAR 2-2008, Equipment, Design, and Installation of Closed-Circuit Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems and ANSI/ASHRAE-15, 2007, Safety Standard for Refrigerating Systems.  All pressure vessels are built according to American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), Section VIII, Division 1, 2007 Edition (with 2009b Addendum), Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Pressure Vessels.  Refrigeration piping design and construction was in accordance with ASME B31.5, 2006, Refrigeration Piping and Heat Transfer Components code.  Electrical design and construction was perfo

In September of 2010 Ajinomoto completed the installation of a new ammonia refrigeration system to accommodate production freezing requirements of a new process line.  Ajinomoto now has two independent refrigeration systems.

The original ammonia refrigeration system (Frick system) has a maximum capacity of 18,500 lbs (at 5.69 lbs/gal).  This capacity is reduced by 20% to a maximum intended inventory of 14,800 lbs.  The new system, referred to as the Mycom system, has a maximum capacity of 6,900 lbs (at 5.69 lbs/gal).  This is reduced by 20% to a maximum intended inventory level of 5,500 lbs.  The total maximum intended inventory on-site of anhydrous ammonia is 21,700 lbs.  It is Ajinomoto's policy that no standby make-up inventory of anhydrous ammonia shall be stored on-site.

The Frick and Mycom refrigeration systems are located in separate, but adjoining, engine rooms and do not share any mechanical components.  They are operated independently and cannot be cross-connected.

1.30  Release Scenarios

The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario, were modeled using RMP*Comp (Version 1.07), a software program developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and EPA.  40 CFR Part 68, Appendix A, provides a toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/l concentration level.  The distances to the toxic endpoint provided by RMP*Comp for the two scenarios noted were overlaid in MARPLOT (Version 4.1.1).  The Western Regional Climate Center (http://www.wrcc.dri.edu/htmlfiles/westwinddir.html) and the National Data Climate Center (http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/mpp/wind1996.pdf) were consulted and provide historical prevailing wind data at Portland International Airport (PDX) of a east southeast (ESE) direction.  This prevailing wind and the toxic end points were used to determine the most probable area of influence in the event of

a major release to the atmosphere of anhydrous ammonia from the Ajinomoto facility.  This area encompasses a 45Â° arc at the toxic endpoint centered on 292Â° radian from the point of origin or release.

Worst-Case
The worst-case scenario modeled the catastrophic failure (rupture) and total discharge of the largest single vessel in both the Frick and Mycom systems.  Catastrophic failure of the high pressure receiver located in the Frick engine room when filled to 80% of the maximum volume amount would release 14,800 pounds of liquid ammonia.  The distance to the toxic endpoint is 1.5 miles which extends beyond the property boundary of Ajinomoto.  This scenario used the following assumptions:  duration of release of 10 minutes @ 814 lbs/min, outside air temperature of 77 Â°F, wind speed of 3.4 miles per hour, rural surroundings (relatively flat, unobstructed terrain), and released in an enclosed space in direct contact with outside air.

Geographic features included in the worst case scenario include the Columbia and Willamette Rivers, the Columbia River Slough, Smith and Bybee Lakes and park, and Kelley Point Park located within approximately 1 mile of the Ajinomoto Frozen Foods facility.  The area is predominantly an industrial use area with no public schools, hospitals, stadiums, or other large public gathering places.

This worst-case scenario would not likely occur unless an act of nature (e.g., earthquake) physically compromised the tank.   The structural integrity of the tank is safeguarded by periodic inspection for mechanical integrity to prevent a rupture due to tank degradation.  The tank is also safeguarded from rupture from over-pressurization.  It is a rated pressure vessel hydro-tested to 375 psi and equipped with 250 psi pressure relief valves. The design specification of the tank only allows a maximum capacity of 80% at 80 degrees Fahrenheit, limiting the total amount of ammonia in the system.

Alternative Scenario
The alternative scenario mod

rmed in accordance with NFPA-70, 2008, National Electrical Code.  Other mechanical components were designed and constructed in accordance with the Oregon Mechanical Specialty Code, 2007.

1.10  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The physical property of anhydrous ammonia that makes it useful as a refrigerant is its low boiling point of -29Â°F at atmospheric pressure.  However, anhydrous ammonia has other physical properties that require precautions and procedures to be followed to protect the environment and public health during a chemical emergency.  It is the policy of Ajinomoto to be in compliance with all applicable federal and state regulations.

Safety at Ajinomoto is inherent in the manner in which anhydrous ammonia is handled.  While the design of the facility incorporates multiple safety devices, safe handling procedures, maintaining mechanical integrity, and appropriate training of our personnel are key aspects to safety at our facility.

A written Process Safety Management (PSM) program that complies with the regulations stipulated by 29 CFR 1910.119 (OAR Â§1910.119) is in place.  A crucial component of this plan is the Emergency Response Plan, developed in compliance with the Emergency Response provisions of 29 CFR 1910.120 (OAR Â§1910.120).  The Emergency Response Plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordination with outside parties to enable coordinated action to effectively deal with unplanned events.

1.20  Facility Description and Substances Handled

Ajinomoto Frozen Foods is a frozen food manufacturing facility that processes, stores, and distributes frozen ready-to-eat foods.  Production requires the use of a refrigeration system to preserve the integrity of processed foods.  This refrigeration process uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant.  Access to the facility is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel, and contractors.

The regulated substance handled at this facility is anhydrous ammonia.

eled a major pipe break (rupture) and a discharge rate of 1,480 lbs/minute for 10 minutes duration.  This represents a major break in a high pressure liquid line from the condensers and loss of the full charge of 14,800 lbs. of ammonia in the Frick system.  This scenario was selected because a release of this type would occur outdoors resulting in the highest potential exposure to off-site receptors.  Several other alternative scenarios can generate the equivalent of a 1 opening in a high pressure liquid line such as:  opening created by a valve sheared off, a large gasket leak, or a pressure relief valve release.  The distance to the toxic endpoint is 1.0 miles which extends beyond the property boundary of Ajinomoto.  This scenario used the following assumptions:  duration of release of 10 minutes @ 1,410 lbs/min, outside air temperature of 77 Â°F, wind speed of 6.7 miles per hour, rural surroundings (relatively flat, unobstructed terrain), and released in an enclosed space in direct contact with outside air.

Geographic features included in the alternative case scenario include the Columbia and Willamette Rivers, the Columbia River Slough, and Smith and Bybee Lakes and park located within approximately Â½ mile of the Ajinomoto Frozen Foods facility.  The area is predominantly an industrial use area with no public schools, hospitals, stadiums, or other large public gathering places.

MARPLOT (Version 4.1.1) system estimated the residential population within the circle limits defined by the endpoint of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios.  The area encompasses a residential receptor population of 54 in 34 housing units (2000 census data - most recent available data) for both worst case and alternative case scenarios.

1.40  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Ajinomoto Frozen Foods complies with EPA  Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  The desig

n and construction of this facility, in 1992 and 2010, was in accordance with published codes and standards recommended by the industry or governmental organizations.

Ajinomoto Frozen Foods written OSHA PSM plan, in accordance with 29 CFR Part 1910.119 (OAR Â§1910.119), incorporates many policies and procedures to ensure safe operation and maintenance of this facility.  Plan elements essential to safe operation of the refrigeration system include employee participation, process hazard information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor safety, pre-startup safety review (PSSR), mechanical integrity, management of change, hot-work permits, incident investigation, emergency response and planning, and compliance audits.  This plan will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary by the Ajinomoto Frozen Foods.

Training is provided to ensure that each employee involved in operating the refrigeration system has been trained in an overview of the process, the operating procedures, and safety considerations.  This training uses guidelines developed by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) and Refrigeration Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA).  Only qualified maintenance personnel operate the refrigeration system.  This minimizes the chances of inadvertent error in operation that could lead to a release of ammonia.  Startup, shutdown, and any system adjustments are handled by these qualified operators.
 
1.50  Five-Year Accident History

There has been no significant release of ammonia at Ajinomoto Frozen Foods since the startup in 1992.

1.60  Emergency Response Program

Ajinomoto Frozen Foods has a written Emergency Response Plan to ensure that precautions and procedures are in place to protect employee and public health and safety during a chemical emergency.  It complies with the provisions of OR-OSHA Emergency Response regulations, OAR Â§1910.120.  The Emergency Response Plan includes pre-emergency planning

and coordinating with outside parties. This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events.  This plan has been provided to and reviewed with the Portland Fire and Rescue.

The approach in the development of this plan has been to identify the ammonia emergencies most likely to occur at Ajinomoto Frozen Foods and establish precautions and procedures to protect life safety and health during an emergency.  The refrigeration process has back-up prevention systems to keep processing malfunctions from becoming ammonia release emergencies.  If an emergency does occur, the following response personnel, facilities, and equipment are in place:  incident command center, emergency alarm and communication system, safe rooms, evacuation plans and assembly points, and personal protective equipment.

It is the policy of Ajinomoto Frozen Foods that employees shall not take offensive counter-measures to control or contain an uncontrolled or major ammonia release.  These situations are emergencies and employees shall only take the following actions: 1) identify a release, 2) notify plant supervisory personnel, 3) evacuate as directed, and 4) isolate or contain the release from an uncontaminated or safe location.  Only in the event of a minor release (e.g. small valve packing leak, draining of compressor oil, or maintenance tasks) shall Ajinomoto employees enter a contaminated area.  These situations are not classified as emergencies.  Vapor level concentrations shall be monitored and respirators with ammonia cartridges shall be worn.  No entry shall be permitted to the area with concentration levels above 300 ppm.
 
The role and procedures for obtaining external emergency assistance have been formally established with the Portland Fire and Rescue, including the Portland HazMat Team 6.  Portland Fire and Rescue and Ajinomoto shall notify any potential off-site receptors.

All Ajinomoto Frozen Foods personnel are trained to f

ulfill their designated responsibilities in an emergency.  Mock emergency drills are held periodically to maintain familiarity with response actions and identify plan elements requiring improvement.

This plan shall be reviewed annually and updated as necessary.

1.70  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Any upgrades or extensive maintenance work performed in the future will be in compliance with codes and standards applicable at that time.  The 2010 expansion of the refrigeration system with the addition of the Mycom system incorporated revised codes and standards that improve overall safety and reduce the potential for an off-site release.  Among these changes is the routing of pressure relief vent piping to a water diffusion tank.  Anhydrous ammonia has a very strong affinity for and readily dissolves in water.  At 68Â°F, about 700 volumes of vapor can be dissolved in one volume of water to make a solution containing 34 percent ammonia by weight.  This solution of ammonia in water is called ammonium hydroxide or aqueous ammonia which minimizes vapor releases to the surrounding environment.

All Ajinomoto Frozen Foods personnel are trained to fulfill their designated responsibilities in an emergency.  Mock emergency drills are held periodically to maintain familiarity with response actions and identify elements requiring improvement.

The most recent Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the Frick system was performed in January 2007 and for the Mycom system in September 2010.  Priority Lists of Recommendations was compiled for implementation for each system.
